Award.AwardTitle: Control of Epitaxial Graphene Layers on Silicon Carbide
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Description: The research performed in this project aims to understand and improve the formation of graphene on the (000-1) surface of SiC (the C-face). Prior work has identified a new interface structure for graphene on the C-face, occurring when the graphene is formed in a low-pressure disilane environment. Further research of this graphene formation mechanism is performed in this project. Decoupling of the C-face interface layer from the SiC is also studied, using hydrogen or oxygen gases. The electronic properties of the graphene are characterized, in collaborative studies with other scientists. Insulating layers such as boron nitride are epitaxially deposited on the graphene, as a first step towards the formation of graphene-insulator-graphene junction. Methods are explored for further deposition of a second layer of graphene on the boron nitride.

Non-technical Description: Graphene, a two-dimensional monolayer of carbon, has been intensively studied for the past decade because of the unique transport properties of electrons in the material. For large-area production of graphene (as needed for electronic devices and circuits), a leading method is the formation on silicon carbide (SiC). This research project focuses on formation mechanisms for graphene on SiC, particularly on its C-face. The project also provides broad multi-disciplinary training to graduate students in the nanotechnology field. Additionally, the PI presents annual lectures to middle and high school students on nanotechnology, as well as teaching an undergraduate course on Nanoscience and Nanotechnology. The graphene-related research of this project is used to enhance the content of these lectures, providing the students with an apt example of a current topic in nanoscience and nanotechnology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Graphene is a material consisting of a single atomic layer of carbon atoms, arranged in a hexagonal lattice. This material has been made, and studied, by many scientists around the world over the past 10 years. The main interest in graphene arises from the way in electrons move through the material; they do so much faster than in other materials, holding promise for the development of faster electronic devices (such as transistors) made from the material.

In our research, we studied various new methods for forming graphene and other related materials, and we also developed new methods of characterizing the material (that is, learning about how all the atoms are arranged). Several studies of this sort were performed:

(1) Our first project concerned the surface of silicon carbide crystals, on which graphene forms naturally when the crystals are heated in vacuum. These silicon carbide crystals have two different crystal faces, one known as the silicon face (Si-face) and the other as the carbon face (C-face). Most graphene-related research on silicon carbide has employed the Si-face, but for our study we wanted to see how graphene forms on the C-face. Some prior studies had reported graphene of exceptional quality on the C-face, although the manner in which it was formed was not well understood. In our work, we heated the silicon carbide at an atmophere containing disilane (Si2H6), and we observed the formation of a new atomic arrangement on the surface. We call this a "root(43)" arrangement, referring to a part of its structural arrangement. Understanding the root(43) arrangement in detail could, in principle, allow us to understand many of the details of how the graphene forms and how we could improve its formation. We conducted a series of experimental and theoretical studies concerning the root(43) arrangement, and in the end we were able to construct a model for the structure that matches the experiments quite well. The structure turns out of contain silicon atoms located ("intercalated") in between the graphene on the surface and the underlying silicon carbide. We predict that under slightly different conditions, a better structure (from the point of view of graphene formation) should form, containing just hydrogen, but not silicon, between the graphene and the silicon carbide. Experiments are continuing in an effort to form that structure.

(2) Our second project dealt with data from a "low-energy electron microscope" (LEEM). With the LEEM, electrons can be sent towards a surface, and we measure the number of reflected electrons as a function of the electron energy. This measurement yields a "spectrum" which is characteristic of the atomic arrangement on the surface; indeed, it forms a sort of "fingerprint" of the surface structure. Previously, interpretation of these spectra was very difficult, if not impossible, since the way in which the atomic arrangement influences the spectrum of reflected electrons is quite complex. However, in our study we developed a new theoretical tool by which these reflectivity spectra can be predicted, for a given atomic arrangement. Comparison of the predicted spectra with experiment thus allows a determination of the surface structure.We have applied this new tool to the study of various surface, including graphene on nickel surfaces.

(3) In a third study, we deposited single atomic layer of hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) on a graphene layer, which itself was formed on  silicon carbide crystal (on the Si-face of the silicon carbide). The h-BN deposition was accomplished using borazine, (BH)3(NH)3, which decomposes on the surface to form the h-BN.
